entry.title: Frost Advisory issued October 24 at 1:57PM MDT until October 25 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures near freezing will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...Most of east central, north central, and northeast Colorado, except the Denver/Boulder metro area.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 9 AM MDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 3:50PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
At 349 PM AST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Arecibo, moving north at 15 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Arecibo, Isabela, Camuy, Quebradillas, Hatillo, San Sebastian, Rafael Capo, San Antonio, Bajadero, Hato Arriba, La Alianza, Rafael Gonzalez, Quebrada, Juncal, Animas, Carrizales, Piedra Gorda, Cacao, Mora, and Sabana Hoyos.
entry.cap:areaDesc: North Central; Central Interior; Northwest; Western Interior; Mayaguez and Vicinity

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued October 24 at 1:47PM MDT until October 24 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 215, 216, and 238 through 251.
* TIMING...Until 6 PM MDT this evening.
* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 16 percent, rising through the afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread. Avoid outdoor burning and any activity that may produce a spark and start a wildfire.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 2:24PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There continues to be an increased risk of fire spread into this evening. Relative humidity values have dropped to the 30 to 40 percent range across much of the area. These low relative humidity values are combined with north to northwest winds around 15 mph with 20 to 25 mph gusts, temperatures in the mid to upper 60s, and abundant sunshine. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control. Winds will diminish fairly quickly this evening after sunset.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values will be lower on Friday, but winds should not be as strong. Burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued October 25 at 3:39AM ChST until October 25 at 6:45AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Saipan and Tinian.
* WHEN...Until 645 AM ChST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 339 AM ChST, gauge reports indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 2 and 3.6 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Garapan, Dandan, China Town, Tanapag, As Mahetog, Koblerville, San Jose (Tinian Municipality), Chalan Kanoa I, San Antonio, Chalan Kanoa II, Chalan Kanoa III, San Roque, Kagman, Chalan Kanoa IV, Kagman III, Gualo Rai, Afetnas, Chalan Piao, Fananganan and Chalan Laulau. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Saipan, MP; Tinian, MP

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 645 AM CHST THIS MORNING

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued October 24 at 7:31AM HST until October 26 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF ADVISORY FOR ALL EAST FACING SHORES THROUGH SATURDAY...
.A moderate to large, medium period NNE (010-030 degrees) swell will produce advisory level surf along east-facing shores through Saturday. Swell and subsequent surf will peak early Friday then slowly decline through the weekend.
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 10 feet increasing to 8 to 12 feet on Friday.
* WHERE...East facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Maui, Molokai, and Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Moderate. Strong breaking waves and strong currents will make swimming dangerous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Olomana; Maui Windward West; Kauai East; Koolau Windward; Molokai Southeast; Windward Haleakala; Big Island East; Big Island North

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST SATURDAY

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued October 24 at 8:43AM AKDT until October 24 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Northwest winds 40 to 55 mph with gusts up to 75 to 85 mph expected.
* WHERE...Alaska Peninsula, especially King Cove and False Pass.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...High winds may move loose debris, damage property, and cause power outages. Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The worst conditions are expected from early Thursday morning through early Thursday afternoon, especially in areas where the terrain will enhance winds. While the worst of the winds should begin subsiding by late Thursday afternoon, expect gusty winds to persist through Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Alaska Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKDT THIS EVENING

entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Middlesex, Western Monmouth, Mercer, Salem, Gloucester, Camden, Northwestern Burlington, Ocean, Cumberland, Atlantic, Cape May and Southeastern Burlington.
* TIMING...Until 6 PM EDT today.
* WINDS...Northwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.

* TEMPERATURES...Up to 70.
* IMPACTS...The combination of very dry conditions, low relative humidity, and gusty winds will result in favorable conditions for the rapid spread of fires. Any fires that develop may become difficult to contain, especially cross the Pine Barrens region.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 10:51AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Above Lake Harney affecting Seminole County.
.The river at Geneva near Lake Harney is forecast to continue a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage over the next 5 days. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River near Lake Harney should stay up to date on the forecast this week and prepare for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Above Lake Harney...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Above Lake Harney.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Water begins to move into homes in low lying areas along the river. Flooding around the Black Hammock area near Lake Jesup.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Thursday was 9.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 9.5 feet. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Seminole, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 10:45AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Sanford affecting Seminole County.
.The river at Sanford is forecast to continue a slow decline into Minor Flood Stage later today or tonight. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Sanford should be prepared for prolonged minor flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Sanford...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1045 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Sanford.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Water begins to move over sea wall around Lake Monroe and rises into grassy areas around the sea wall. Water begins to encroach on Seminole Boulevard.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 7.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 4.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 AM EDT Thursday was 7.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 6.9 feet. - Flood stage is 5.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Seminole, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 10:40AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Deland affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The river level at Deland remains in Major Flood Stage, but is forecast to gradually fall to Moderate flood by this weekend. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Deland should be prepared for continued flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Deland...Major flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1045 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Deland.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 5.3 feet, Major flooding occurs to many structures and marinas along the river and in the Hontoon Island area.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 5.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 3.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 AM EDT Thursday was 5.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 5.3 feet. - Flood stage is 4.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 24 at 10:34AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The Saint Johns River at Astor remains in Major Flood Stage but is forecast to continue a gradual decline through the weekend into next week, falling into Moderate flood. Residents and interests along the Saint Johns River should be prepared for prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Major flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1045 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 4.0 feet, Major flooding occurs with water entering many structures on canals and along the river. Long duration flooding will occur, with levels taking weeks to months to return below flood stage. Water rescues will be necessary. River Road becomes inaccessible, with 1 to 2 feet water depth in numerous homes on Wildhog, Possum, Bonnet and Snail roads. Roads along Blue Creek are inaccessible with major flooding of homes on Otter, Branch and Chestnut roads. Camp South Moon Road and Juno Trail are inaccessible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 4.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 AM EDT Thursday was 4.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 4.1 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued October 24 at 8:58AM CDT until October 24 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS Norman OK
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Norman has issued a Red Flag Warning for gusty winds, hot temperatures, low humidities, and dry vegetation which is in effect from noon today to 10 PM CDT this evening.
* WINDS...South to southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts 35 to 45 mph. Wind shift to the north 15 to 25 mph with gusts around 30 mph expected this evening.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 23 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 93.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
* SEVERITY...
FUELS (ERC)...90th+ percentile...5 (out of 5).
WEATHER...Near Critical...2 (out of 5).
FIRE ENVIRONMENT...7 (out of 10).

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 9:32AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
Elevated fire conditions are expected due to dry conditions and gusty winds. Relative humidity values around 30 percent are expected, along with sustained northwesterly winds of 15 to 20 mph and gusts of 25 to 30 mph. This will result in the rapid drying of fine fuels.
Residents and visitors are urged to exercise caution if handling open flames or equipment that create sparks. Also, dispose of cigarette butts, matches, and other flammable items in appropriate containers. Keep vehicles off of dry grass and obey local burn bans. Most dry grasses, dead leaves, and other tree litter could easily ignite and spread fire quickly.
For more information about wildfire danger, burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit your state's forestry or environmental protection website.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 3:51AM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
Elevated fire weather conditions are expected across the lower Maryland eastern shore in the wake of a dry cold frontal passage. Northwest wind gusts of 20 to 30 mph, in combination with forecast minimum Relative Humidity values of 25 to 35% will present an increased risk for the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Residents are urged to exercise caution handling any potential ignition source...including machinery... cigarettes...and matches. Be sure to properly discard all smoking materials. Any dry grasses and tree litter that ignite will have the potential to spread quickly.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dorchester; Wicomico; Somerset; Inland Worcester

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 3:43AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There is an increased risk of fire spread Today. Relative humidity values are expected to fall to around 30 to 40 percent across much of the area. This will be combined with north to northwest winds near around 15 mph with 20 to 25 mph gusts, temperatures in the mid to upper 60s, and abundant sunshine. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values may be lower on Friday, but winds should not be as strong. Burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 3:07AM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
A combination of dry and windy conditions will create an elevated risk of wildfire spread across mainly southern Pennsylvania today. Relative humidity values dip to the 30 to 40 percent range this afternoon accompanied by wind gusts out of the northwest between 15 and 25 MPH. The higher gusts will be along and to the southeast of I-81.
Residents are urged to exercise caution if handling any potential ignition sources, such as machinery, cigarettes, or matches. If dry grasses and tree litter begin to burn, the fire will have the potential to spread rapidly.
For more information about wildfire danger and wildfire prevention and education, please visit the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources website at http://dcnr.pa.gov/Communities/Wildfire.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 4:46PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
A tropical disturbance, known as Invest 98W from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, continues to slowly develop west of Chuuk near 7.9N 147.8E. This system will slowly continue westward before turning towards the Marianas sometime late Friday into Saturday, gradually strengthening as it does so. Computer model guidance continues to highlight the potential for this developing system to pass through the Marianas.
POTENTIAL IMPACTS: - Sustained winds exceeding 30 mph.
- Locally heavy rainfall potentially causing flash flooding, especially in areas of poor drainage or in the valleys of hilly terrain.
- Hazardous surf and marine conditions.
As this disturbance is still poorly organized, uncertainty remains high regarding the timing of its eventual consolidation and turn to the northwest. Continue to monitor latest forecasts from weather.gov/gum and information from your local emergency management offices.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

cap:parameter.value: DEVELOPING TROPICAL DISTURBANCES WILL AFFECT THE REGION THROUGH THE WEEKEND... ...RAIN AND WIND POTENTIAL DEPENDENT ON THE EVENTUAL MOTION

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 24 at 2:50PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
A strong westerly monsoon pattern persists across western Micronesia. The worst conditions are found between Yap and Chuuk and areas south. Satellite data has shown squalls racing southeastward at 30-40 mph, between 140E and 152E, bringing brief heavy showers, strong to damaging gusts, and rapidly spiking seas in the 10-15 ft range. Northwesterly flow between Yap and Chuuk will turn westerly Saturday, possibly increasing as 98W, currently near Chuuk, shifts farther west-northwest. The duration of this monsoonal flow and its impacts will be dependent on 98W and its motion. 98W is the subject of a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, meaning development of a tropical cyclone (tropical depression) is likely within 24 hours. For more information on Invest 98W, see bulletins issued by JTWC under WMO header WTPN21 PGTW.
This monsoonal pattern will make inter-island travel hazardous and potentially dangerous at times so travel is discouraged through the rest of week and into the weekend. Watch out for high surf along west and north facing reefs and pay attention to surf and sea conditions.
Residents across Yap and Chuuk States should continue to monitor local weather forecasts from the National Weather Service in Guam, and for additional information from your local Weather Service Office and emergency management. Visit weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts for the latest weather information from the National Weather Service.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chuuk Lagoon; Yap

cap:parameter.value: STRONG MONSOONAL PATTERN CONTINUES ACROSS EASTERN YAP AND WESTERN CHUUK STATES

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued October 23 at 7:06PM AKDT until October 26 at 7:00AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southeast winds 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 60 mph possible.
* WHERE...Hydaburg and Craig on Prince of Wales Island.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...High winds could blow around unsecured objects, damage property and cause power outages. Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest confidence in gusts with inital frontal passage into the southern panhandle by Friday evening into Saturday morning. In addition, there is a 30% chance of wind gusts up to 60 mph by a secondary front pushing into the southern panhandle by Saturday evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 23 at 1:43PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Thursday, October 24, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Thursday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Harris; Inland Brazoria; Inland Galveston; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula
